content.webTitle: San Francisco Ballet: scorching dancers leave their hearts in London

fields.headline: San Francisco Ballet: scorching dancers leave their hearts in London
fields.bodyText: 1) This is a company with a hunger for new work. The second week of their London run has brought six UK premieres, added to the four last week. Director Helgi Tomasson’s commissions made this tour a genuinely exciting event. 2) Brits are held in high esteem on the West Coast. Five out of the 10 choreographers across the season are British, four American, one Russian. 3) Only one of those 10 choreographers is a woman – Cathy Marston. 4) Nobody is crazily reinventing ballet, technically or conceptually. It’s more about pulling at its edges, loosening its strings, or putting it in casual wear. In Bespoke, Stanton Welch plays it straight in a work that feels as if it’s made up of the dancers’ favourite steps, letting them show off their best bits with zinging smiles. David Dawson’s Anima Animus goes for bodies presenting themselves as lean, lithe and knowingly beautiful (a little thin on depth and spirit, though). In Bound To, Christopher Wheeldon excels, as ever, in meaningful pas de deux. Trey McIntyre’s Your Flesh Shall Be a Great Poem is the most unclassical of the lot, with pedestrian touches, gleeful scampering, and a soulful solo that feels like movement drawn from inside dancer Benjamin Freemantle’s body. 5) Narrative ballet is still in the minority. The most common approach is loosely thematic, unspecific feels, emotion without always obvious motivation. 6) Platonic male duets are now totally normalised. Whether that’s one cheeky lift among the usual male-female mix in Bespoke, or tender interactions in McIntyre or Wheeldon’s work. 7) Cinematic minimalism is a favourite soundtrack. Philip Glass must currently be the most overused composer in dance (having knocked Arvo Pärt off the top spot) and his Tirol Concerto propels the supple flurry of Liam Scarlett’s steps in Hummingbird. But the heavy string repetitions of Ezio Bosso’s score for Anima Animus drive down the energy on stage rather than revving it up. 8) Modern life gets a look-in. See: Wheeldon’s dancers with faces glued to phone screens; pop music from Björk to Keaton Henson, American singer Chris Garneau and electronic outfit M83, which leads to... 9) Justin Peck pretty much lives up to the hype. The New York City Ballet sensation’s Hurry Up, We’re Dreaming is very balletic, but feels fresh, with a youthful authenticity (and not just because the dancers are wearing metallic leggings and plimsolls). It’s set to M83’s music, which sounds like the sun going down at a festival, when the cold has just started to seep in, but the buzz keeps you warm. Peck mirrors the simplicity of pop in clear melodic lines, repetitive hooks and builds – Dores André flying in a series of turns and lifts, again and again. Like its music, Peck gives the viewer clear direction in clever but never convoluted choreography. 10) The dancers are brilliant. Shout-outs for Sasha De Sola, who transformed from the prim perfection of a pageant queen in Bespoke to earnest, lyrical dancer of Hummingbird in the time it took to change costumes; to Angelo Greco, who landed a double tour with such flawless style it made me laugh out loud; and the infectiously joyful jumping of Wei Wang. San Francisco Ballet are at Sadler’s Wells, London, until 8 June
